[24/09/2024, 18:46:09] Andie: ## Sharing Your Calendar

1. Open Outlook and navigate to the Calendar view

2. Click on the "Share" button at the top of the calendar view

3. In the "Share with" box, type the name or email address of the person you want to share your calendar with

4. Choose the level of access you want to grant:

   - *Can view when I'm busy*: Shows only your availability, without details

   - *Can view titles and locations*: Shows when you're busy, plus event titles and locations

   - *Can view all details*: Allows the person to see all information in your calendar

   - *Can edit*:Gives permission to make changes to your calendar

   - *Delegate*: Allows the person to edit your calendar and share it with others

5. Click "Send" to share your calendar

*Sequential Task Forgetfulness:*

Starting to make tea, putting the kettle on, then completely forgetting you were making tea and finding the kettle boiled hours later
Going upstairs to get something specific, arriving upstairs and having no idea what you went up for
Starting to write an email, getting distracted mid-sentence, then completely losing track of what you were trying to communicate

*Working Memory Issues:*

Someone tells you a room number or phone extension at work, but by the time you reach for a pen it's gone
Can't hold numbers in your head to do mental math - they seem to "slip away"
Having to immediately write down or act on information because if you wait even a few seconds, it vanishes

*Task Sequencing Memory:*

Knowing how to do something but suddenly "forgetting" the steps mid-task
Having to consciously think through the order of getting dressed
Losing track of where you are in a familiar task if interrupted

*Daily Life Impact:*

Repeatedly checking if you've locked doors because you can't remember doing it
Forgetting items you use daily (keys, phone) despite having specific places for them
Missing appointments despite having them written down
Losing track of time while doing tasks â€<This message was edited>

Good afternoon, Opprah.
Apologies for the delay in response. We have been advised the following as per below with regards to the concerns you have noted:
Rationale for declining shared care in this case:
Shared care agreements are designed for NHS specialist services. NICE guideline NG87 (Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder: diagnosis and management) states that shared care should be considered where a patient is stable and the specialist provides a clear treatment plan. This presumes the specialist is part of the NHS pathway.
Private diagnoses do not automatically transfer into NHS prescribing. NHS England and multiple ICBs have confirmed that GPs are not obliged to prescribe ADHD medication following a private assessment. Patients who choose private routes are expected to continue prescribing with that provider.
Clinical expertise and monitoring requirements. ADHD medications are controlled drugs with significant monitoring needs (blood pressure, pulse, weight, side effects, efficacy). Practices are not resourced or trained to provide this monitoring outside of an NHS specialist framework.
Contractual and funding limitations. Prescribing ADHD medication after private diagnosis is not part of the GMS contract. We do not hold the prescribing budget or capacity for the required monitoring.
Patient safety. Responsibility for prescribing must remain with the diagnosing specialist until the patient is formally accepted into NHS services.
Alternative NHS pathways available to patients:
Referral to local NHS ADHD services for assessment and treatment initiation.
Use of the NHS â€œRight to Chooseâ€ pathway, which allows referral to certain providers commissioned by the NHS.
Until such referral is accepted, prescribing and monitoring should remain with the private provider.
Summary position:  Our practice will only accept shared care requests from NHS providers, and even then, acceptance depends on our clinical expertise and capacity to monitor the patient safely. ADHD medication following private diagnosis remains the responsibility of the private prescriber. Patients wishing to access NHS prescribing should be referred via the Right to Choose pathway or local NHS ADHD services.
This position is consistent with NICE guidance, NHS England policy, and the contractual limitations of general practice.
Kind regards,

Bellevue Medical Centre

[05/12/2025, 13:47:12] Andie: idk likkle e.g. *How You Would Use It (The Practical Steps)*

*The "Yasss" Moment:* You're on Instagram. You see a look. You get the "10 dopamine tokens."

*The Hijack (Capture):* Instead of letting it become an "open tab," you immediately hit the "Share" button and send it to a specific note in your notes app called "Fashion Inspiration" or a specific Pinterest board. You might add a quick tag like #datenight or #gottamakeit.

*The Release (Closing the Tab):* Because you have captured it in a system you trust, your brain can now let it go. The tab is closed. The RAM is cleared. The overwhelm disappears.

*The Creation (Retrieval):* Weeks later, when you're actually planning an outfit or have time to create, you open your "Second Brain." All your inspiration is there, organized and waiting for you. You can now act on it with clarity and focus.
